transformed_texts: I believe, there are a few aspects where the Catholic Church ought to evolve. They've been addressing their dwindling attendance, and I reckon it's due to their rather rigid stances on certain matters. For instance, they've been pretty staunch on behalf of gay marriage, abortion, and contraception. Their positions, while steadfast, seem a tad outdated. I think if they embraced a more contemporary perspective, they'd find their flock less likely to wander. I've witnessed a shift in public opinion, with some people turning against the Church, not aligning with their views on these topics. People are simply losing patience with their stance. Take abortion, for example; if one supports it, they might feel uncomfortable in an environment where it's deemed entirely wrong. The same goes for issues like gay marriage. I don't see why female priests are off the table or why priests can't have families. After all, most people balance a job and a family life. Perhaps allowing priests to marry wouldn't change their actions, but it's a matter I'd like to see explored. It's hard to say for certain, but I do believe it's worth considering.

So, I'm not against gay marriage, really. It's like, whether someone is born that way or whatever, it doesn't seem like it's a choice they make. I mean, I was born straight, and someone else is born gay, it doesn't feel like a conscious decision that they should be held responsible for. So, I think it's wrong to say a man and a woman can get married but two people of the same sex can't. I wouldn't want the federal government to be involved in this. It just feels like it's not their place to interject in people's lives. This isn't about security or morality, it's just how people are born. And they shouldn't be punished for that. That's it.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized, for the simple reason that there's no compelling argument against it. Many people fear that homosexual couples threaten the traditional family, but it's a complex issue with numerous aspects that make it distinct from heterosexual unions. It's like comparing two sides of the same coin—heads and tails, yet they are essentially the same. There are civil rights involved, like property taxes and healthcare, which are not available to gay couples in the same way. For instance, if a gay couple is in the hospital, their partner can't visit or be in the room if they're not considered family. It seems silly to spend your life with someone and not grant them these basic rights. Scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar success rates and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. The issue is that people get caught up on the idea that homosexuals want to get married in a church, but they're asking for a legal document from the government. If church and state involvement is removed, it shouldn't be an issue. It's like segregation—separate but unequal. Gay couples and their relationships are the same in many ways, and people worry about adoption and community issues, but the main concern is how children of gay couples will adjust. In New York City, they have special schools for children of gay parents because of bullying. Parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight ones. The federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state and amend the constitution to reflect this. President Bush has strong religious views against it, similar to his stance on abortion and stem cell research. Most arguments against it are moral in nature, but morality varies among individuals, and it's unethical to enforce one group's morality on the entire country. The government should not create an amendment based on religious beliefs, considering recent controversies like the pledge of allegiance's "under God" clause. Many people are anti-gay because they believe it's a result of psychological damage from childhood trauma or personality defects, but this is not supported by research. Institutions that have studied this issue, like the American Psychological Association, have debunked these myths, and people should rely on actual research rather than popular opinion or cultural beliefs.

Well first off, I work in a hospital pharmacy during the summer, you know? Just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it lacks beneficial properties. It's just not beneficial to have it readily available to the public. Absolutely not. But for medicinal purposes? Yes. Just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it's not beneficial. It's not. You know what I mean?

Yeah, there are plenty of illegal drugs that pharmacies use, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocets, you name it. They're controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. And if you deny their benefits just because there's a taboo around marijuana, then it's pointless for me. You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I don't think it's similar to alcohol because, sure, if you abuse it, that can lead to bad things. But if you abuse alcohol too, you know, it can too. It's a tough one. I'd say we could integrate it, make it legal gradually, not all at once, because then it would be abused. But first, you gotta remove that taboo around marijuana. Then people might use it responsibly.

Yeah, people have such a bad image of marijuana because it's an illegal drug, but it's not that bad for you. It's not like heroine or cocaine or something like that. So, if we get rid of that image, people might be able to use it responsibly, and certainly for medical purposes.

I reckon the church has become more adaptable to the twenty-first century. It's not as stringent as it once was. I remember, when I was younger, I'd always attend church every Sunday, dressed in my cute little dresses and matching shoes and purse. Back then, I was in a private school where I'd see all my friends there on weekends. Now, though, they've introduced a teenager mass that's cut down to thirty minutes and people dress a lot more casually, especially during the summer. Sometimes, you'd see folks coming in straight from the beach or families running in late. Even during the morning masses where I'd always dress up, folks are sporting jeans and khakis now. It seems to be more laid-back, overall. I don't delve into the politics of the church, but that's the biggest change I've noticed. It's more casual.

As for the accusations against Catholic priests and pedophilia, I don't think these could have been prevented by allowing female priests or married priests. I believe men who become pedophiles can't change that nature just because they're allowed to get married. They choose to become priests, and there are other religions where they're allowed to get married. If they genuinely want to practice their faith and be married, maybe they should consider a different faith.

I think pedophilia is largely genetic. I don't think it's something people are brought up to become. It can't be hidden through marriage, and it often comes out. Therefore, I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent it, though if they knew and tried to cover it up, they're to blame. But I don't think in all cases they knew.

I don't have any other thoughts concerning the Catholic Church.

Alright, so at first I was fine with the idea of the Iraq war, but I think we were all still grappling with the aftermath of September 11th. It seems like the Bush administration used the attacks as an excuse to go into Iraq, claiming that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which we now know was false. That's what really gets my goat about the whole thing.

I mean, they lied to the American people, plain and simple. Even Colin Powell, who made a big speech at the UN about it, admitted later that he wasn't convinced by the evidence. That's just about as bad as it gets. The Bush administration acted like they had no regard for the Constitution, and it seems like they've been trying to water it down ever since September 11th. It's like they were just looking for a reason to go to war.

It's all really been dragging on for too long. I think if we pulled out now, it would be a mess. There's a risk the country could descend into civil war and more people would die. The UN and the U.S. are talking about a coalition of neighboring countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia stepping in to restore order, but that might just make things worse in the long run. Iraq's sovereignty would be a major issue, and it seems like the interim government is falling apart. The Parliament isn't doing much, and even the Prime Minister doesn't seem to have much control over what's happening. Plus, we're still dealing with radical elements vying for power, like Muqtada al-Sadr. The political situation is pretty chaotic, to say the least.

I'm not sure if it's right to make it legal or for a state to even declare it as such. I believe the constitution has already spoken on this matter, stating a clear separation between church and state. It seems that those pushing for it are choosing one church's beliefs over another, as most Catholics and Christians are against it. I think it's more about personal religion than anything else. The government shouldn't interfere with what the churches allow or disallow. Making an amendment would be contradictory to the constitution's established clauses. It's not about restricting the government, but restricting people's freedoms. I don't see why the federal government should be involved in this. The president's push for an amendment is just a reflection of his personal Catholic beliefs, which doesn't make it a good reason to restrict people's choices. I think it's best left to the churches. It's not about economy or any other reason, but rather about personal views. I've pretty much said all there is to say on this.

The government played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003
I myself am pretty much against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think it’s a repeat of many ways of the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from past mistakes.
The war in Iraq has been a tremendous loss for American soldiers, and the government was not prepared for the aftermath and the chaos that followed. They removed the Iraqi government and tried to implant a democratic one, similar to what they did in Vietnam. They were trying to remove Communists and uphold democracy, but it’s been a long and hard ordeal.
I think the government was not as prepared as they should have been. They didn’t plan for all possible outcomes. We’re still there today, almost at the end of 2006, and many American troops are still dying. Trying to train the Iraqi troops and police forces to police their own country is a long process.
I think the government tried to deceive the American people into thinking it would be a short and successful stay in Iraq. We shouldn’t be naïve about the time it takes to implement a new form of government. In our own country, democracy was a long struggle. It just isn’t an easy thing to do. The government made it seem like it would be relatively easy.

Before going into war, one of the reasons was that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction. No weapons were ever found, yet places like North Korea, which we knew had them, we are not attacking. I don’t think the US government is being thorough or truthful enough in their decisions.
I just hope it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

I feel like the war has been dragged on far too long. The initial purpose seemed noble—restoring democracy in a country lacking a fair political system. But I think we've lost sight of that goal and are now fighting for the sake of asserting our power. Maybe the original motivations were tainted by George Bush's father's past disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the primary aim was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that would be a just cause. However, I don't think our reason for continuing the war is as clear-cut now. It feels like we're still engaged in the conflict just to prove we're a powerful nation, and we don't want to end the war without a decisive victory. I think it's been going on for far too long. The country's government should be able to handle itself by now. We've spent billions of dollars on this war while our own economy is struggling with issues like poverty and infrastructure. The money could be better spent on improving our own communities, such as fixing public roads and schools, or addressing healthcare needs. It's a drain on our economy to keep fighting a war that's lost its purpose.

I gotta say, I believe gender discrimination is still very much a reality in the United States. It's not just about women, though. It's about the specific industry you're in too. Like, overall, women face the glass ceiling. Even today, many struggle to find a position where they're not working under a man due to societal conditioning. I mean, people just aren't comfortable with the idea of a woman being in charge. And it's the same for men in fields like fashion or staying at home as a parent. Society has this archaic view that men should be the breadwinners, so when a man stays at home, people look down on him. Or in fashion, people don't take men seriously, especially if they're straight. It's like, "How can you understand fashion if you're a guy?" It's all about stereotypes. I think we need to keep working at this because change is slow. Women are starting to take on more leadership roles, and stay-at-home dads are becoming more accepted, but it's a slow process. We need to keep promoting these roles, not forcing them. If we do it too fast, people will resist. And yeah, it's not just men vs. women, it's also about where you come from and how you speak. If you're from a rural area and have poor grammar but are highly intelligent, other men might not take you seriously. It's complex, but it's real.

Let me set the record straight; they didn't make marijuana legal, they just took it off the criminal books and turned it into more of a traffic fine sort of deal. You know, like getting cited and not arrested. Now, if someone gets caught, it's not like they'll get a job offer or anything, but it's still not as bad as a drug charge. I mean, sure, it's not a walk in the park, but at least it's not as severe. They say decriminalizing it costs a fortune in terms of legal fees, court time, and all that. It's a lot of money that could be used for other things. Like Denver, for instance, where people are more open-minded - they've probably got better things to spend their money on now, like education and social programs. But hey, it's not like marijuana should be sold everywhere. It's still a bit of a taboo in many places, and I don't think people just want it out in the open. Plus, it can affect people differently. Some people might end up in the hospital, or even worse. I mean, alcohol has its own set of problems, and you never know how someone's going to react to it. It's a tough call, but I guess we have to take it day by day.

I'd say yes, traditions are crucial, no doubt about it. They offer a sense of continuity and familiarity that’s comforting. But, adapting to change is equally vital. Consider the rigid ways of the Catholic Church, where weekly attendance and strict adherence to doctrine are the norm. It's almost as if they judge those who don't meet their standards, and that extends to those of other faiths too. My parents are a prime example—my mom was Catholic, my dad Episcopalian. They wouldn't allow our parents to marry in the Catholic Church, despite their love for each other. Talk about a lack of tolerance! You know the Church teaches to love others, but in practice, it's often hypocritical. They're rooted in outdated traditions, yet they persist. I believe priests marrying wouldn't solve the problem of pedophilic behavior. After all, abusers act on their impulses, regardless of their marital status. I don't think marriage would stop that kind of behavior. It's just a different realm. Sure, it might deter some, but it's not a panacea.

Well, I'm still grappling with this issue, so I can't say which side has the right of it. It's a tricky matter, really, right on the edge of where church and state meet. How to define marriage is a slippery slope. It's hard to do without causing offense. So, I'm not sure, but I think we might just treat all civil unions the same, like they are, two people united. Why should the government poke into what kind of union it is, whether it's a sacrament or not? And if you're married, why not just call it a civil union? It's just two people coming together, right? Now, if the states can agree on this, they should push to make it federal law. But banning gay marriage with a constitutional amendment? That's just absurd. The constitution shouldn't be amended for such a divisive but not necessarily crucial issue. It's just too small a cause to amend the constitution over. So, no.

I grew up in a Christian household, so homosexuality is sort of a grey area for me. I have many gay friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather something each state decides on its own. It's not like the president can live in every state and make the decision for everyone. Some states are democratic and will push for gay marriage, while others are republican and won't. If you live in a state that decides to legalize it, you should respect that decision. After all, you chose to live there. I think homosexuals deserve the same opportunities as heterosexuals, and it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I don't think Bush should decide the whole country should be against gay marriage. He doesn't live in every state, and he shouldn't have that kind of power. Some things should be left up to individual states. Plus, he'll be out of office in two years, and if a democratic president lifts the ban, it's just going to go back and forth. It should be up to the states, as they'll have to live with the decision. I don't agree with his ban on it.

transformed_texts: I believe, there are a few aspects where the Catholic Church ought to evolve. They've been addressing their dwindling attendance, and I reckon it's due to their rather rigid stances on certain matters. For instance, they've been pretty staunch on behalf of gay marriage, abortion, and contraception. Their positions, while steadfast, seem a tad outdated. I think if they embraced a more contemporary perspective, they'd find their flock less likely to wander. I've witnessed a shift in public opinion, with some people turning against the Church, not aligning with their views on these topics. People are simply losing patience with their stance. Take abortion, for example; if one supports it, they might feel uncomfortable in an environment where it's deemed entirely wrong. The same goes for issues like gay marriage. I don't see why female priests are off the table or why priests can't have families. After all, most people balance a job and a family life. Perhaps allowing priests to marry wouldn't change their actions, but it's a matter I'd like to see explored. It's hard to say for certain, but I do believe it's worth considering.

So, I'm not against gay marriage, really. It's like, whether someone is born that way or whatever, it doesn't seem like it's a choice they make. I mean, I was born straight, and someone else is born gay, it doesn't feel like a conscious decision that they should be held responsible for. So, I think it's wrong to say a man and a woman can get married but two people of the same sex can't. I wouldn't want the federal government to be involved in this. It just feels like it's not their place to interject in people's lives. This isn't about security or morality, it's just how people are born. And they shouldn't be punished for that. That's it.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized, for the simple reason that there's no compelling argument against it. Many people fear that homosexual couples threaten the traditional family, but it's a complex issue with numerous aspects that make it distinct from heterosexual unions. It's like comparing two sides of the same coin—heads and tails, yet they are essentially the same. There are civil rights involved, like property taxes and healthcare, which are not available to gay couples in the same way. For instance, if a gay couple is in the hospital, their partner can't visit or be in the room if they're not considered family. It seems silly to spend your life with someone and not grant them these basic rights. Scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar success rates and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. The issue is that people get caught up on the idea that homosexuals want to get married in a church, but they're asking for a legal document from the government. If church and state involvement is removed, it shouldn't be an issue. It's like segregation—separate but unequal. Gay couples and their relationships are the same in many ways, and people worry about adoption and community issues, but the main concern is how children of gay couples will adjust. In New York City, they have special schools for children of gay parents because of bullying. Parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight ones. The federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state and amend the constitution to reflect this. President Bush has strong religious views against it, similar to his stance on abortion and stem cell research. Most arguments against it are moral in nature, but morality varies among individuals, and it's unethical to enforce one group's morality on the entire country. The government should not create an amendment based on religious beliefs, considering recent controversies like the pledge of allegiance's "under God" clause. Many people are anti-gay because they believe it's a result of psychological damage from childhood trauma or personality defects, but this is not supported by research. Institutions that have studied this issue, like the American Psychological Association, have debunked these myths, and people should rely on actual research rather than popular opinion or cultural beliefs.

Yeah, there are plenty of illegal drugs that pharmacies use, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocets, you name it. They're controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. I don't think it's similar to alcohol because, sure, if you abuse it, that can lead to bad things. But if you abuse alcohol too, you know, it can too. It's a tough one. I reckon the church has become more adaptable to the twenty-first century. It's not as stringent as it once was. I remember, when I was younger, I'd always attend church every Sunday, dressed in my cute little dresses and matching shoes and purse. Back then, I was in a private school where I'd see all my friends there on weekends. Now, though, they've introduced a teenager mass that's cut down to thirty minutes and people dress a lot more casually, especially during the summer. Sometimes, you'd see folks coming in straight from the beach or families running in late. Even during the morning masses where I'd always dress up, folks are sporting jeans and khakis now. It seems to be more laid-back, overall. I don't delve into the politics of the church, but that's the biggest change I've noticed. It's more casual.

As for the accusations against Catholic priests and pedophilia, I don't think these could have been prevented by allowing female priests or married priests. I believe men who become pedophiles can't change that nature just because they're allowed to get married. They choose to become priests, and there are other religions where they're allowed to get married. If they genuinely want to practice their faith and be married, maybe they should consider a different faith.

I think pedophilia is largely genetic. I don't think it's something people are brought up to become. It can't be hidden through marriage, and it often comes out. Therefore, I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent it, though if they knew and tried to cover it up, they're to blame. But I don't think in all cases they knew.

I don't have any other thoughts concerning the Catholic Church.

Alright, so at first I was fine with the idea of the Iraq war, but I think we were all still grappling with the aftermath of September 11th. It seems like the Bush administration used the attacks as an excuse to go into Iraq, claiming that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which we now know was false. That's what really gets my goat about the whole thing.

I mean, they lied to the American people, plain and simple. Even Colin Powell, who made a big speech at the UN about it, admitted later that he wasn't convinced by the evidence. That's just about as bad as it gets. The Bush administration acted like they had no regard for the Constitution, and it seems like they've been trying to water it down ever since September 11th. It's like they were just looking for a reason to go to war.

It's all really been dragging on for too long. I think if we pulled out now, it would be a mess. There's a risk the country could descend into civil war and more people would die. The UN and the U.S. are talking about a coalition of neighboring countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia stepping in to restore order, but that might just make things worse in the long run. Iraq's sovereignty would be a major issue, and it seems like the interim government is falling apart. The Parliament isn't doing much, and even the Prime Minister doesn't seem to have much control over what's happening. Plus, we're still dealing with radical elements vying for power, like Muqtada al-Sadr. The political situation is pretty chaotic, to say the least.

I'm not sure if it's right to make it legal or for a state to even declare it as such. I believe the constitution has already spoken on this matter, stating a clear separation between church and state. It seems that those pushing for it are choosing one church's beliefs over another, as most Catholics and Christians are against it. I think it's more about personal religion than anything else. The government shouldn't interfere with what the churches allow or disallow. Making an amendment would be contradictory to the constitution's established clauses. It's not about restricting the government, but restricting people's freedoms. I don't see why the federal government should be involved in this. The president's push for an amendment is just a reflection of his personal Catholic beliefs, which doesn't make it a good reason to restrict people's choices. I think it's best left to the churches. It's not about economy or any other reason, but rather about personal views. I've pretty much said all there is to say on this.

To start from the beginning, I don’t think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war
Before invading Iraq. They tried to link the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, even though they didn’t have much to do with each other. The government played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003
I myself am pretty much against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think it’s a repeat of many ways of the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from past mistakes.
The war in Iraq has been a tremendous loss for American soldiers, and the government was not prepared for the aftermath and the chaos that followed. They removed the Iraqi government and tried to implant a democratic one, similar to what they did in Vietnam. They were trying to remove Communists and uphold democracy, but it’s been a long and hard ordeal.
I think the government was not as prepared as they should have been. They didn’t plan for all possible outcomes. We’re still there today, almost at the end of 2006, and many American troops are still dying. Trying to train the Iraqi troops and police forces to police their own country is a long process.
I think the government tried to deceive the American people into thinking it would be a short and successful stay in Iraq. We shouldn’t be naïve about the time it takes to implement a new form of government. In our own country, democracy was a long struggle. It just isn’t an easy thing to do. The government made it seem like it would be relatively easy.

Before going into war, one of the reasons was that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction. No weapons were ever found, yet places like North Korea, which we knew had them, we are not attacking. I don’t think the US government is being thorough or truthful enough in their decisions.
I just hope it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

I feel like the war has been dragged on far too long. The initial purpose seemed noble—restoring democracy in a country lacking a fair political system. But I think we've lost sight of that goal and are now fighting for the sake of asserting our power. Maybe the original motivations were tainted by George Bush's father's past disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the primary aim was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that would be a just cause. However, I don't think our reason for continuing the war is as clear-cut now. It feels like we're still engaged in the conflict just to prove we're a powerful nation, and we don't want to end the war without a decisive victory. I think it's been going on for far too long. The country's government should be able to handle itself by now. We've spent billions of dollars on this war while our own economy is struggling with issues like poverty and infrastructure. The money could be better spent on improving our own communities, such as fixing public roads and schools, or addressing healthcare needs. It's a drain on our economy to keep fighting a war that's lost its purpose.

I've got a question, buddy. You see, some dude went and checked out an online post and something bad was prevented. I mean, it's pretty clear that stuff you post on the internet is there for everyone to see, right?

On sites like Myspace, you gotta be friends with someone to see their profile. You're giving them permission to check it out, so if someone did that, they've agreed to it. I'm not saying it's right, but it's their choice.

It's tough to know, though, if someone's looking at your profile for a reason or just stumbling upon it. I don't think it's fair for one person to spend days looking through everyone's profiles just to find something fishy. But if they're looking for evidence of something specific, that's different.

I've got a Facebook myself, and it bothers me that there are creepers out there who can see my stuff. I've seen a show where a guy got a girl's screen name in less than a minute and talked to her instantly over IM. I'd never meet someone like that, but I've had classmates who know my screen name and my interests. It's a weird feeling, knowing they can see so much about me. I try to limit what I put up, but it's tricky because I use it to stay in touch with friends. I only accept people I know, but you never really know who can see what.

I gotta say, I believe gender discrimination is still very much a reality in the United States. It's not just about women, though. It's about the specific industry you're in too. Like, overall, women face the glass ceiling. Even today, many struggle to find a position where they're not working under a man due to societal conditioning. I mean, people just aren't comfortable with the idea of a woman being in charge. And it's the same for men in fields like fashion or staying at home as a parent. Society has this archaic view that men should be the breadwinners, so when a man stays at home, people look down on him. Or in fashion, people don't take men seriously, especially if they're straight. It's like, "How can you understand fashion if you're a guy?" It's all about stereotypes. I think we need to keep working at this because change is slow. Women are starting to take on more leadership roles, and stay-at-home dads are becoming more accepted, but it's a slow process. We need to keep promoting these roles, not forcing them. If we do it too fast, people will resist. And yeah, it's not just men vs. women, it's also about where you come from and how you speak. If you're from a rural area and have poor grammar but are highly intelligent, other men might not take you seriously. It's complex, but it's real.

Let me set the record straight; they didn't make marijuana legal, they just took it off the criminal books and turned it into more of a traffic fine sort of deal. You know, like getting cited and not arrested. Now, if someone gets caught, it's not like they'll get a job offer or anything, but it's still not as bad as a drug charge. I mean, sure, it's not a walk in the park, but at least it's not as severe. They say decriminalizing it costs a fortune in terms of legal fees, court time, and all that. It's a lot of money that could be used for other things. Like Denver, for instance, where people are more open-minded - they've probably got better things to spend their money on now, like education and social programs. But hey, it's not like marijuana should be sold everywhere. It's still a bit of a taboo in many places, and I don't think people just want it out in the open. Plus, it can affect people differently. Some people might end up in the hospital, or even worse. I mean, alcohol has its own set of problems, and you never know how someone's going to react to it. It's a tough call, but I guess we have to take it day by day.

I'd say yes, traditions are crucial, no doubt about it. They offer a sense of continuity and familiarity that’s comforting. But, adapting to change is equally vital. Consider the rigid ways of the Catholic Church, where weekly attendance and strict adherence to doctrine are the norm. It's almost as if they judge those who don't meet their standards, and that extends to those of other faiths too. My parents are a prime example—my mom was Catholic, my dad Episcopalian. They wouldn't allow our parents to marry in the Catholic Church, despite their love for each other. Talk about a lack of tolerance! You know the Church teaches to love others, but in practice, it's often hypocritical. They're rooted in outdated traditions, yet they persist. I believe priests marrying wouldn't solve the problem of pedophilic behavior. After all, abusers act on their impulses, regardless of their marital status. I don't think marriage would stop that kind of behavior. It's just a different realm. Sure, it might deter some, but it's not a panacea.

Well, I'm still grappling with this issue, so I can't say which side has the right of it. It's a tricky matter, really, right on the edge of where church and state meet. How to define marriage is a slippery slope. It's hard to do without causing offense. So, I'm not sure, but I think we might just treat all civil unions the same, like they are, two people united. Why should the government poke into what kind of union it is, whether it's a sacrament or not? And if you're married, why not just call it a civil union? It's just two people coming together, right? Now, if the states can agree on this, they should push to make it federal law. But banning gay marriage with a constitutional amendment? That's just absurd. The constitution shouldn't be amended for such a divisive but not necessarily crucial issue. It's just too small a cause to amend the constitution over. So, no.

I grew up in a Christian household, so homosexuality is sort of a grey area for me. I have many gay friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather something each state decides on its own. It's not like the president can live in every state and make the decision for everyone. Some states are democratic and will push for gay marriage, while others are republican and won't. If you live in a state that decides to legalize it, you should respect that decision. After all, you chose to live there. I think homosexuals deserve the same opportunities as heterosexuals, and it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I don't think Bush should decide the whole country should be against gay marriage. He doesn't live in every state, and he shouldn't have that kind of power. Some things should be left up to individual states. Plus, he'll be out of office in two years, and if a democratic president lifts the ban, it's just going to go back and forth. It should be up to the states, as they'll have to live with the decision. I don't agree with his ban on it.

transformed_texts: I believe, there are a few aspects where the Catholic Church ought to evolve. They've been addressing their dwindling attendance, and I reckon it's due to their rather rigid stances on certain matters. For instance, they've been pretty staunch on behalf of gay marriage, abortion, and contraception. Their positions, while steadfast, seem a tad outdated. I think if they embraced a more contemporary perspective, they'd find their flock less likely to wander. I've witnessed a shift in public opinion, with some people turning against the Church, not aligning with their views on these topics. People are simply losing patience with their stance. Take abortion, for example; if one supports it, they might feel uncomfortable in an environment where it's deemed entirely wrong. The same goes for issues like gay marriage. I don't see why female priests are off the table or why priests can't have families. After all, most people balance a job and a family life. Perhaps allowing priests to marry wouldn't change their actions, but it's a matter I'd like to see explored. It's hard to say for certain, but I do believe it's worth considering.

So, I'm not against gay marriage, really. It's like, whether someone is born that way or whatever, it doesn't seem like it's a choice they make. I mean, I was born straight, and someone else is born gay, it doesn't feel like a conscious decision that they should be held responsible for. So, I think it's wrong to say a man and a woman can get married but two people of the same sex can't. I wouldn't want the federal government to be involved in this. It just feels like it's not their place to interject in people's lives. This isn't about security or morality, it's just how people are born. And they shouldn't be punished for that. That's it.

I believe that gay marriage should be legalized, for the simple reason that there's no compelling argument against it. Many people fear that homosexual couples threaten the traditional family, but it's a complex issue with numerous aspects that make it distinct from heterosexual unions. It's like comparing two sides of the same coin—heads and tails, yet they are essentially the same. There are civil rights involved, like property taxes and healthcare, which are not available to gay couples in the same way. For instance, if a gay couple is in the hospital, their partner can't visit or be in the room if they're not considered family. It seems silly to spend your life with someone and not grant them these basic rights. Scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar success rates and relationship satisfaction as heterosexual couples. The issue is that people get caught up on the idea that homosexuals want to get married in a church, but they're asking for a legal document from the government. If church and state involvement is removed, it shouldn't be an issue. It's like segregation—separate but unequal. Gay couples and their relationships are the same in many ways, and people worry about adoption and community issues, but the main concern is how children of gay couples will adjust. In New York City, they have special schools for children of gay parents because of bullying. Parenting skills are the same in gay couples as in straight ones. The federal government should legalize gay marriage in every state and amend the constitution to reflect this. President Bush has strong religious views against it, similar to his stance on abortion and stem cell research. Most arguments against it are moral in nature, but morality varies among individuals, and it's unethical to enforce one group's morality on the entire country. The government should not create an amendment based on religious beliefs, considering recent controversies like the pledge of allegiance's "under God" clause. Many people are anti-gay because they believe it's a result of psychological damage from childhood trauma or personality defects, but this is not supported by research. Institutions that have studied this issue, like the American Psychological Association, have debunked these myths, and people should rely on actual research rather than popular opinion or cultural beliefs.

Yeah, there are plenty of illegal drugs that pharmacies use, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocets, you name it. They're controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. And if you deny their benefits just because there's a taboo around marijuana, then it's pointless for me. You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I don't think it's similar to alcohol because, sure, if you abuse it, that can lead to bad things. But if you abuse alcohol too, you know, it can too. It's a tough one. I'd say we could integrate it, make it legal gradually, not all at once, because then it would be abused. But first, you gotta remove that taboo around marijuana. Then people might use it responsibly.

Yeah, people have such a bad image of marijuana because it's an illegal drug, but it's not that bad for you. It's not like heroine or cocaine or something like that. So, if we get rid of that image, people might be able to use it responsibly, and certainly for medical purposes.

I reckon the church has become more adaptable to the twenty-first century. It's not as stringent as it once was. I remember, when I was younger, I'd always attend church every Sunday, dressed in my cute little dresses and matching shoes and purse. Back then, I was in a private school where I'd see all my friends there on weekends. Now, though, they've introduced a teenager mass that's cut down to thirty minutes and people dress a lot more casually, especially during the summer. Sometimes, you'd see folks coming in straight from the beach or families running in late. Even during the morning masses where I'd always dress up, folks are sporting jeans and khakis now. It seems to be more laid-back, overall. I don't delve into the politics of the church, but that's the biggest change I've noticed. It's more casual.

As for the accusations against Catholic priests and pedophilia, I don't think these could have been prevented by allowing female priests or married priests. I believe men who become pedophiles can't change that nature just because they're allowed to get married. They choose to become priests, and there are other religions where they're allowed to get married. If they genuinely want to practice their faith and be married, maybe they should consider a different faith.

I think pedophilia is largely genetic. I don't think it's something people are brought up to become. It can't be hidden through marriage, and it often comes out. Therefore, I don't think the church could have done anything to prevent it, though if they knew and tried to cover it up, they're to blame. But I don't think in all cases they knew.

I don't have any other thoughts concerning the Catholic Church.

Alright, so at first I was fine with the idea of the Iraq war, but I think we were all still grappling with the aftermath of September 11th. It seems like the Bush administration used the attacks as an excuse to go into Iraq, claiming that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which we now know was false. That's what really gets my goat about the whole thing.

I mean, they lied to the American people, plain and simple. Even Colin Powell, who made a big speech at the UN about it, admitted later that he wasn't convinced by the evidence. That's just about as bad as it gets. The Bush administration acted like they had no regard for the Constitution, and it seems like they've been trying to water it down ever since September 11th. It's like they were just looking for a reason to go to war.

It's all really been dragging on for too long. I think if we pulled out now, it would be a mess. There's a risk the country could descend into civil war and more people would die. The UN and the U.S. are talking about a coalition of neighboring countries like Syria and Saudi Arabia stepping in to restore order, but that might just make things worse in the long run. Iraq's sovereignty would be a major issue, and it seems like the interim government is falling apart. The Parliament isn't doing much, and even the Prime Minister doesn't seem to have much control over what's happening. Plus, we're still dealing with radical elements vying for power, like Muqtada al-Sadr. The political situation is pretty chaotic, to say the least.

I'm not sure if it's right to make it legal or for a state to even declare it as such. I believe the constitution has already spoken on this matter, stating a clear separation between church and state. It seems that those pushing for it are choosing one church's beliefs over another, as most Catholics and Christians are against it. I think it's more about personal religion than anything else. The government shouldn't interfere with what the churches allow or disallow. Making an amendment would be contradictory to the constitution's established clauses. It's not about restricting the government, but restricting people's freedoms. I don't see why the federal government should be involved in this. The president's push for an amendment is just a reflection of his personal Catholic beliefs, which doesn't make it a good reason to restrict people's choices. I think it's best left to the churches. It's not about economy or any other reason, but rather about personal views. I've pretty much said all there is to say on this.

The war in Iraq
Well
To start from the beginning, I don’t think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war
Before invading Iraq. They tried to link the invasion to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, even though they didn’t have much to do with each other. The government played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003
I myself am pretty much against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think it’s a repeat of many ways of the Vietnam War. The government should have learned from past mistakes.
The war in Iraq has been a tremendous loss for American soldiers, and the government was not prepared for the aftermath and the chaos that followed. They removed the Iraqi government and tried to implant a democratic one, similar to what they did in Vietnam. They were trying to remove Communists and uphold democracy, but it’s been a long and hard ordeal.
I think the government was not as prepared as they should have been. They didn’t plan for all possible outcomes. We’re still there today, almost at the end of 2006, and many American troops are still dying. Trying to train the Iraqi troops and police forces to police their own country is a long process.
I think the government tried to deceive the American people into thinking it would be a short and successful stay in Iraq. We shouldn’t be naïve about the time it takes to implement a new form of government. In our own country, democracy was a long struggle. It just isn’t an easy thing to do. The government made it seem like it would be relatively easy.
Well, it’s a difficult decision because I felt that way in the election. One of my reasons for considering voting for George Bush was to let him finish what he started. Once you go in and you’ve been there for so long, how can you abandon them?
It’s probably something we should see to its finish, but again there’s the consideration of the American casualties. How much is too much to keep risking for a free democratic Iraq?
Why is it just Iraq? Why aren’t we doing this to all these other countries? I think the big reason is the oil issue. It’s where we get our oil from, and it’s usually all about money and controlling resources.
Before going into war, one of the reasons was that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction. No weapons were ever found, yet places like North Korea, which we knew had them, we are not attacking. I don’t think the US government is being thorough or truthful enough in their decisions.
I just hope it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

I feel like the war has been dragged on far too long. The initial purpose seemed noble—restoring democracy in a country lacking a fair political system. But I think we've lost sight of that goal and are now fighting for the sake of asserting our power. Maybe the original motivations were tainted by George Bush's father's past disputes with Saddam Hussein. If the primary aim was to give democracy to a country ruled by a tyrant, that would be a just cause. However, I don't think our reason for continuing the war is as clear-cut now. It feels like we're still engaged in the conflict just to prove we're a powerful nation, and we don't want to end the war without a decisive victory. I think it's been going on for far too long. The country's government should be able to handle itself by now. We've spent billions of dollars on this war while our own economy is struggling with issues like poverty and infrastructure. The money could be better spent on improving our own communities, such as fixing public roads and schools, or addressing healthcare needs. It's a drain on our economy to keep fighting a war that's lost its purpose.

I gotta say, I believe gender discrimination is still very much a reality in the United States. It's not just about women, though. It's about the specific industry you're in too. Like, overall, women face the glass ceiling. Even today, many struggle to find a position where they're not working under a man due to societal conditioning. I mean, people just aren't comfortable with the idea of a woman being in charge. And it's the same for men in fields like fashion or staying at home as a parent. Society has this archaic view that men should be the breadwinners, so when a man stays at home, people look down on him. Or in fashion, people don't take men seriously, especially if they're straight. It's like, "How can you understand fashion if you're a guy?" It's all about stereotypes. I think we need to keep working at this because change is slow. Women are starting to take on more leadership roles, and stay-at-home dads are becoming more accepted, but it's a slow process. We need to keep promoting these roles, not forcing them. If we do it too fast, people will resist. And yeah, it's not just men vs. women, it's also about where you come from and how you speak. If you're from a rural area and have poor grammar but are highly intelligent, other men might not take you seriously. It's complex, but it's real.

Let me set the record straight; they didn't make marijuana legal, they just took it off the criminal books and turned it into more of a traffic fine sort of deal. You know, like getting cited and not arrested. Now, if someone gets caught, it's not like they'll get a job offer or anything, but it's still not as bad as a drug charge. I mean, sure, it's not a walk in the park, but at least it's not as severe. They say decriminalizing it costs a fortune in terms of legal fees, court time, and all that. It's a lot of money that could be used for other things. Like Denver, for instance, where people are more open-minded - they've probably got better things to spend their money on now, like education and social programs. But hey, it's not like marijuana should be sold everywhere. It's still a bit of a taboo in many places, and I don't think people just want it out in the open. Plus, it can affect people differently. Some people might end up in the hospital, or even worse. I mean, alcohol has its own set of problems, and you never know how someone's going to react to it. It's a tough call, but I guess we have to take it day by day.

I'd say yes, traditions are crucial, no doubt about it. They offer a sense of continuity and familiarity that’s comforting. But, adapting to change is equally vital. Consider the rigid ways of the Catholic Church, where weekly attendance and strict adherence to doctrine are the norm. It's almost as if they judge those who don't meet their standards, and that extends to those of other faiths too. My parents are a prime example—my mom was Catholic, my dad Episcopalian. They wouldn't allow our parents to marry in the Catholic Church, despite their love for each other. Talk about a lack of tolerance! You know the Church teaches to love others, but in practice, it's often hypocritical. They're rooted in outdated traditions, yet they persist. I believe priests marrying wouldn't solve the problem of pedophilic behavior. After all, abusers act on their impulses, regardless of their marital status. I don't think marriage would stop that kind of behavior. It's just a different realm. Sure, it might deter some, but it's not a panacea.

Well, I'm still grappling with this issue, so I can't say which side has the right of it. It's a tricky matter, really, right on the edge of where church and state meet. How to define marriage is a slippery slope. It's hard to do without causing offense. So, I'm not sure, but I think we might just treat all civil unions the same, like they are, two people united. Why should the government poke into what kind of union it is, whether it's a sacrament or not? And if you're married, why not just call it a civil union? It's just two people coming together, right? Now, if the states can agree on this, they should push to make it federal law. But banning gay marriage with a constitutional amendment? That's just absurd. The constitution shouldn't be amended for such a divisive but not necessarily crucial issue. It's just too small a cause to amend the constitution over. So, no.

I grew up in a Christian household, so homosexuality is sort of a grey area for me. I have many gay friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but rather something each state decides on its own. It's not like the president can live in every state and make the decision for everyone. Some states are democratic and will push for gay marriage, while others are republican and won't. If you live in a state that decides to legalize it, you should respect that decision. After all, you chose to live there. I think homosexuals deserve the same opportunities as heterosexuals, and it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. I don't think Bush should decide the whole country should be against gay marriage. He doesn't live in every state, and he shouldn't have that kind of power. Some things should be left up to individual states. Plus, he'll be out of office in two years, and if a democratic president lifts the ban, it's just going to go back and forth. It should be up to the states, as they'll have to live with the decision. I don't agree with his ban on it.
